newsitem.title: USA: U.S. corporate bonds fall from highs, end stronger.
newsitem.headline: U.S. corporate bonds fall from highs, end stronger.

text.p: U.S. high-grade corporate bonds retreated from midday highs but held on to some gains by the close after turbulent early trade ignited by the U.S. August payrolls report, dealers said.
Investment-grade corporates road the coattails of U.S. Treasuries which dove in a lightening-quick sell-off and recovery immediately following the release of the in-line payrolls report.
The 30-year long bond rose from over a point off to close up 17/32 at 95-18/32 to yield 7.11 percent.
Wall Street stocks tracked the rally in Treasuries.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended up 52.90 to 5659.86, fueling junk bonds which closed up 1/8 to 1/4, dealers said.
Trade volume was light in both high-grade and high-yield arenas. Dealers said the recent drought of new issuance along with Friday's volatile underlying markets has dampened secondary trade activity.
But post payrolls, new issuance is seen picking up as long as currnet interest rate levels hold, dealers said.

Numerous finance and bank names are circulating around the new issue market include Wells Fargo, Signet Bank, Nationsbank, Key Bank, Australia/New Zealand Bank, and Argentaria Bank with a $250 million yankee offering, sources said.
No new issues priced on Friday.
In spot trade, Mellon Bank's 11-year paper, which debued on Thursday, closed issue-bid, dealers said.
Ralphs Grocery 10.45 percent paper was quoted up 7/8, while the company's 11 percent paper was up 5/8, traders said.
Pathmark 9.625 percent debt also traded up 1/2 at 95 bid.

The Labor Department reported a sharp decline to 5.1 percent in the nation's unemployment rate, the lowest since March, 1989. August nonfarm payrolls were up 250,000 while the average hourly earnings component was up a stronger-than-expected 0.5 percent.
